title: Boris Johnson mocks Extinction Rebellion protesters as 'nose-ringed crusties'
text:

Arrogant Boris Johnson has unleashed a mocking attack on Extinction Rebellion protesters just a few yards from where they set up camp outside Downing Street.

The Prime Minister branded the youthful activists "nose-ringed... uncooperative crusties" who are "littering" the road with "heaving hemp-smelling bivouacs."

And speaking at the launch of a Margaret Thatcher biography in Whitehall's Banqueting House, he claimed the 1980s Tory PM took climate change seriously "long before Greta Thunberg".

His provocative comments come after he demanded police use the "full force of the law" against climate protesters - days after his own actions were found unlawful by the Supreme Court.

Scotland Yard had arrested 280 demonstrators by 9.30pm last night but scores more set up camp on Whitehall and 30,000 are expected to descend on the capital today.

(Image: James Veysey/REX)

(Image: SIPA USA/PA Images)

Old Etonian millionaire Mr Johnson set his green credentials aflame with an address to the launch of Charles Moore's third volume on the 1980s PM.

He said: "I am afraid that the security people didn’t want me to come along tonight.

"They said the road was full of uncooperative crusties and protesters all kinds littering the road.

"And they said there was some risk that i would be egged.

"And so I immediately asked my the faint hearts in my private office what would Margaret Thatcher do? What would Maggie do?

(Image: REUTERS)

"If she could take the extraordinary risk of sending a taskforce half way round the world through tumultuous seas to recapture the Falklands, I think she would have crossed the road to speak at the banqueting hall."

He added: "I hope that when we go out from this place tonight, and we are waylaid by importunate nose-ringed climate change protesters, we remind them that she was also right about greenhouse gases.

"She took it seriously long before Greta Thunberg.

"And the best thing possible for the education of the denizens of the heaving hemp-smelling bivouacs that now litter Trafalgar Square and Hyde Park... would be for them to stop blocking the traffic and buy a copy of Charles’s magnificent book so that they can learn about a true feminist, green and revolutionary who changed the world for the better."

London is bracing for a second day of traffic disruptions as Extinction Rebellion's planned two weeks of global climate change protests continue.

(Image: SIPA USA/PA Images)

Celebrity Ruby Wax was one of several famous faces taking part in the protests at Trafalgar Square yesterday, along with actress Juliet Stevenson and models Daisy Lowe and Arizona Muse.

Truly Madly Deeply star Stevenson said: "It's a very wonderful action today.

"We can't any longer allow governments to do this so we have to make it clear that there is no more time.

"There's a long tradition in this country of people saying governments are not acting, we have to make them realise how urgent this is."

Yet No10 commanded police to use the "full force of the law".

The Prime Minister's official spokesman said: "People have the right to protest peacefully but they must do so within the law.

"It is essential that people can continue to go about their business getting to and from work, visiting families and have access to vital public services including emergency services, hospitals and schools.

"The right to peaceful protest does not extend to unlawful activity - the Government expects the police to take a firm stance against protesters who significantly disrupt the lives of others and to use the full force of the law."

Transport Secretary Grant Shapps also demanded police clear tents from Whitehall. "No one should be able to set up a tent in the middle of the road," he told Sky News.
description: The arrogant Prime Minister tore into the climate activists and claimed Margaret Thatcher was the true environmentalist after telling police to use the 'full force of the law'
